results.title: India: two girls one camera
results.creator_credit: Food For Thought, Kylie Washington and Citt Williams
results.brief_description: Two childhood friends capture their thoughts and feelings as they travel to India and encounter a clash between Eastern and Western cultures which varies from the trivial to the tragic.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Food For Thought, Kylie Washington and Citt Williams

results.title: India: the struggle for food
results.brief_description: Following the life of a farmer in the upper Ganges Valley, we see the problems which beset India’s food production. the use of primitive methods of farming, the growing rural population and the resulting migration of farmers to the cities, all contribute to low crop yields. Under government auspices, the Community Development Program is trying to improve farming methods and enrich village life.

results.title: India: Delhi and Agra, Rajasthan and Kashmir
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Delhi, capital of India, and steeped in history, is the perfect start to any trip to India, the land of fascinating contrasts. Visit the bustling bazaars, the Red Fort, former citadel of the Moghul emperors…and New Delhi with its stately structures and underground markets, dungeons and sprawling ruins. Agra home of the Taj Mahal. Stroll down Agra’s exotic streets and marvel at its attractions…the forts, palaces and tombs of past emperors. Rajasthan and Kashmir - enchanting palaces, impregnable forts, uncompromising deserts and tranquil lakes. Kashmir - overlooked by the mighty Himalayas. Its wonderful mountain streams, forests and beautiful lakes with their famous houseboats. Moghul gardens and romantic architecture, make Kashmir the Jewel in the Crown of India.

results.title: India: an Introduction
results.creator_credit: Worldview Productions, Sam Bryan, Michael Camerini and James MacDonald
results.brief_description: Shows India as a nation varied in cultures, religions and customs, in climate, dress, diet, history, and language. Looks at industries and farming. Animated maps are used to locate the Himalayas, farmlands, paths of the monsoon rains, population density and India’s many alphabets and languages.

results.title: India: A Personal Encounter
results.creator_credit: Michael Dillon Film Enterprises and Michael Dillon
results.brief_description: Sir Edmund Hillary and friends journey from the ocean at India’s southernmost tip to the snows of Himalayas, a pilgrimage similar to those taken by millions of Hindus each year. Travelling by such unconventional means as canal boat, camel, elephant and bullock cart as well as by foot, bicycle, train and an old river sailboat, they were able to see the real India, through the tropical backwaters of Kerala, the deserts of Rajasthan, along the Ganges and into the Himalayas. They saw snake boat races, a heart-stopping martial arts display with flexible swords, a gathering of 10,000 camels, an ancient fort city in the Thar desert and much, much more. A stunningly photographed record of the remarkable sights and experiences of this remarkable journey - an enthralling family adventure.

results.title: India: a northern menu
results.creator_credit: Screenscope, Hal Weiner and Marilyn Weiner
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World of Cooking”.
Just as India is a rich blend of cultures, Indian cooking is a blend of exotic spices. Chef Simon Fernandes and his assistants unveil some aspects of their ancient cuisine.

results.title: India, Pakistan and the Union of India
results.brief_description: An account of the geography and sociological conditions existing in present-day India: Hindu and Muslim religions; important economic problems as experienced by a typical peasant family; industry in India; climatic conditions - a period of drought followed by the monsoon season; the spread of education and its effect on the industrial and agricultural life of the country.

results.title: India welcomes the Queen, 1961
results.creator_credit: British Movietone News and Commonwealth Relations Office
results.brief_description: H.M. the Queen’s tour of India, 1961. Episodes include the Royal arrival at Delhi, splendours of a Durbar at Jaipur, the spectacular Republic Day parade in Delhi, and visits to the Taj Mahal, Durgapur steelworks, the botanical gardens at Bangalore, and the cities of Calcutta, Madras, and the Holy city of Benares.

results.title: India Song
results.brief_description:
In the 1930s, Anne-Marie Stratter lives in Calcutta with her husband, the French Ambassador. During a reception at the Embassy, Anne-Marie dances with her lover, Michael Richardson, unaware of her husband’s glances. Anne-Marie is equally unaware of the passion in the vice-consul’s eyes. The vice-consul declares is passion to Anne-Marie. She rebuffs him. The vice-consul runs off and a heartrending cry tears the stillness of the night. Further viweing: In ‘Son nom de Venise dans Calcutta desert’(1976), Marguerite Duras re-uses the same soundtrack, this time accompanied with images of the Embassy, now deserted, where the action of ‘India Song’ took place. The closing sequence of ‘Son nom de Venise dans Calcutta desert’ is used as the opening sequence for ‘India Song’.

Credits: Producer, Stephane Tchalgadjieff ; director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Bruno Nuytten ; music, Ludwig van Beethoven, Carlos d’Alessio.
Cast: Delphine Seyrig, Michel Lonsdale, Claude Mann, Mathieu Carriere, Didier Flamand, Vernon Dobtcheff.

results.title: India fights kans
results.creator_credit: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
results.brief_description: Shows how kans grass, a deep-rooted weed, has been spreading through the central plains of India, choking food crops. Shows how the Indian Government received aid from the World Bank, and the arrival in 1949 of 300 tractors purchased with the loan. These are shown as they plough deep to uproot the weed, and as they are turned to other uses such as clearing scrub and rain forests. Includes glimpses of Indian peasants celebrating at their harvest festival.
